newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Stowaway twins appear in court on return to NZ.
newsitem.headline: Stowaway twins appear in court on return to NZ.

text.p: Twin sisters found in remote tropical Northern Australia after swimming through shark-infested waters were remanded in custody on their return home to New Zealand on Friday.
The 18-year-old sisters Sarah and Joanne Ingham had been deported and were immediately taken by police to an Auckland court on charges relating to events before they left New Zealand.
They had a tearful reunion with their mother, Jeanette Ingham.
The twins made a 30-second court appearance and were remanded to appear in Nelson District Court on Monday. They were refused bail because they had absconded previously.

The twins had been missing since April 20, when they leapt overboard with a 27-year-old Malaysian seaman from the Malaysian container ship Bunga Terasek in Princess Charlotte Bay, north of Cairns. The trio were apparently locked in a love triangle.

The pair stowed away on the ship in early February after failing to appear in a New Zealand court on drink-driving and assault charges. The twins and the seaman were found on Wednesday by members of a remote Aboriginal community around 50 km (30 miles) inland at Coen, on the Cape York Peninsula.
They had reportedly paddled 20 km (12 miles) through shark and crocodile-infested waters after leaping from the ship.
Local Aborigines who found them gave them food and, after driving them to an area near Coen, called the police. The trio were eventually found by Aboriginal trackers.
An Aboriginal police tracker, Barry John Port, said on Thursday he believed the trio had survived once they reached the shore by scavenging for seafood.
"They lived on the fish that they caught, oysters and crabs," Port said. "I think it is amazing that they survived."
Some people doubt the twins' story.
Barb Shepherd, a Coen nurse who examined them after their ordeal described their survival as a "cock and bull" story.
"I find the story pretty incredible. Their lips weren't chapped as you'd expect if they'd been in salt water for 18 hours and out in the sun for two weeks," she told The New Zealand Herald newspaper.
She suspects the trio had been picked up and dropped ashore by a prawn trawler, a view shared by North Queensland police.
The lack of insect bites or signs of dehydration and hunger lead Coen Regional Aboriginal Corporation project manager Annelies Vorhuis to doubt the story.
She questioned why they ran away from police and trackers if they had been living off the land for so long.
"If you'd been out in the bush for two weeks, you'd be pretty keen to get into a warm bed and have a hot shower," she said.
